clean_text: Cirque: a large amphitheatre-like form at the head of a mountain valley formed by glacial erosion and the action of frost and the consequent failure of the adjacent rock walls.
raw_text: Cirque: a large amphitheatre-like form at the head of a mountain valley formed by glacial erosion and the action of frost and the consequent failure of the adjacent rock walls.

sentences.text: Cirque: a large amphitheatre-like form at the head of a mountain valley formed by glacial erosion and the action of frost and the consequent failure of the adjacent rock walls.

clean_text: Coastal cells: a unit of subdivision of the coast where the sediment circulates within fixed boundaries, usually defined by headlands.
raw_text: Coastal cells: a unit of subdivision of the coast where the sediment circulates within fixed boundaries, usually defined by headlands.

sentences.text: Coastal cells: a unit of subdivision of the coast where the sediment circulates within fixed boundaries, usually defined by headlands.

clean_text: Conserving natures stage: a relatively modern concept based on flora and fauna being the actors with geodiversity as the stage on which they thrive. It underlines the importance of the interdependence between biodiversity and geodiversity and their coordinated conservation.
raw_text: Conserving natures stage: a relatively modern concept based on flora and fauna being the actors with geodiversity as the stage on which they thrive. It underlines the importance of the interdependence between biodiversity and geodiversity and their coordinated conservation.

sentences.text: Conserving natures stage: a relatively modern concept based on flora and fauna being the actors with geodiversity as the stage on which they thrive.
It underlines the importance of the interdependence between biodiversity and geodiversity and their coordinated conservation.

clean_text: Crystals: a homogeneous solid with naturally formed plane faces. Minerals may present crystals of various sizes and geometric shapes.
raw_text: Crystals: a homogeneous solid with naturally formed plane faces. Minerals may present crystals of various sizes and geometric shapes.

sentences.text: Crystals: a homogeneous solid with naturally formed plane faces.
Minerals may present crystals of various sizes and geometric shapes.

clean_text: Crystalline rocks: old term referring to rocks comprising crystals formed by slow cooling after being subject to intense heat and/or pressure. They can be either metamorphic rocks, such as gneiss, or igneous rocks, such as granite.
raw_text: Crystalline rocks: old term referring to rocks comprising crystals formed by slow cooling after being subject to intense heat and/or pressure. They can be either metamorphic rocks, such as gneiss, or igneous rocks, such as granite (see definitions of the specific rock types in this glossary).

sentences.text: Crystalline rocks: old term referring to rocks comprising crystals formed by slow cooling after being subject to intense heat and/or pressure.
They can be either metamorphic rocks, such as gneiss, or igneous rocks, such as granite.

clean_text: Deposition: the dropping of particles due to gravity that were being carried by water, ice or wind; precipitation of a mineral from a solution.
raw_text: Deposition: (a) the dropping of particles due to gravity that were being carried by water, ice or wind; (b) precipitation of a mineral from a solution.

sentences.text: Deposition: the dropping of particles due to gravity that were being carried by water, ice or wind; precipitation of a mineral from a solution.

clean_text: Doline: an enclosed depression of moderate dimensions that is the fundamental unit of relief in many karst terrains and serves a similar hydrological function to a catchment. The term sinkhole is commonly used as a synonym for a doline.
raw_text: Doline: an enclosed depression of moderate dimensions (<1km wide or deep) that is the fundamental unit of relief in many karst terrains and serves a similar hydrological function to a catchment. The term sinkhole is commonly used as a synonym for a doline.

sentences.text: Doline: an enclosed depression of moderate dimensions that is the fundamental unit of relief in many karst terrains and serves a similar hydrological function to a catchment.
The term sinkhole is commonly used as a synonym for a doline.

clean_text: Dynamic landforms: landforms constantly evolving or on the move, such as sand dunes in deserts and along sea coasts, or features such as sand and gravel bars in river beds, and unstable surface materials of soil and rocks on steep mountain slopes.
raw_text: Dynamic landforms: landforms constantly evolving or on the move, such as sand dunes in deserts and along sea coasts, or features such as sand and gravel bars in river beds, and unstable surface materials of soil and rocks on steep mountain slopes.

sentences.text: Dynamic landforms: landforms constantly evolving or on the move, such as sand dunes in deserts and along sea coasts, or features such as sand and gravel bars in river beds, and unstable surface materials of soil and rocks on steep mountain slopes.

clean_text: Earthquake: sudden violent shaking of the ground, typically causing great destruction, as a result of movements within the earths crust or due to explosive volcanic processes.
raw_text: Earthquake: sudden violent shaking of the ground, typically causing great destruction, as a result of movements within the earths crust or due to explosive volcanic processes.

sentences.text: Earthquake: sudden violent shaking of the ground, typically causing great destruction, as a result of movements within the earths crust or due to explosive volcanic processes.

clean_text: Ecosystems: a dynamic complex of plant, animal and microorganism communities and their non-living environment interacting as a functional unit. It is the sum total of all the abiotic and biotic processes going on, such as biogeochemical cycles and primary production.  Ecosystem functioning: the collective life activities of plants, animals and microbes and the effects these activities  feeding, growing, moving, excreting waste, etc.  have on the physical and chemical conditions of the environment.  Ecosystem services: the benefits people obtain from ecosystems. These include provisioning services, such as food and water production; regulating services, such as flood and disease control; cultural services, such as spiritual, recreational and cultural benefits; and supporting services, such as nutrient cycling, that maintain the conditions for life on Earth. ). Ecosystem services are provided by both geodiversity and biodiversity.  Ecosystem structure: the biophysical architecture of an ecosystem; the composition and arrangement of all the living and non-living physical matter at a location.
raw_text: Ecosystems: a dynamic complex of plant, animal and microorganism communities and their non-living environment interacting as a functional unit. It is the sum total of all the abiotic and biotic processes going on, such as biogeochemical cycles and primary production.  Ecosystem functioning: the collective life activities of plants, animals and microbes and the effects these activities  feeding, growing, moving, excreting waste, etc.  have on the physical and chemical conditions of the environment.  Ecosystem services: the benefits people obtain from ecosystems. These include provisioning services, such as food and water production; regulating services, such as flood and disease control; cultural services, such as spiritual, recreational and cultural benefits; and supporting services, such as nutrient cycling, that maintain the conditions for life on Earth (Millennium Ecosystem Assessment, 2005). ). Ecosystem services are provided by both geodiversity and biodiversity.  Ecosystem structure: the biophysical architecture of an ecosystem; the composition and arrangement of all the living and non-living physical matter at a location.

sentences.text: Ecosystems: a dynamic complex of plant, animal and microorganism communities and their non-living environment interacting as a functional unit.
It is the sum total of all the abiotic and biotic processes going on, such as biogeochemical cycles and primary production.

Ecosystem functioning: the collective life activities of plants, animals and microbes and the effects these activities  feeding, growing, moving, excreting waste, etc.  have on the physical and chemical conditions of the environment.
Ecosystem services: the benefits people obtain from ecosystems.

These include provisioning services, such as food and water production; regulating services, such as flood and disease control; cultural services, such as spiritual, recreational and cultural benefits; and supporting services, such as nutrient cycling, that maintain the conditions for life on Earth. ).
Ecosystem services are provided by both geodiversity and biodiversity.
Ecosystem structure: the biophysical architecture of an ecosystem; the composition and arrangement of all the living and non-living physical matter at a location.

clean_text: Environmental Impact Assessment: an analytical process undertaken prior to decisions being taken on development projects, in an effort to avoid unforeseen adverse consequences. The process involves identifying, predicting, evaluating and mitigating the natural, social and other relevant environmental effects of development proposals.
raw_text: Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA): an analytical process undertaken prior to decisions being taken on development projects, in an effort to avoid unforeseen adverse consequences. The process involves identifying, predicting, evaluating and mitigating the natural, social and other relevant environmental effects of development proposals.

sentences.text: Environmental Impact Assessment: an analytical process undertaken prior to decisions being taken on development projects, in an effort to avoid unforeseen adverse consequences.
The process involves identifying, predicting, evaluating and mitigating the natural, social and other relevant environmental effects of development proposals.

clean_text: Epithermal activity: shallow-depth activity that is low in temperature and pressure, resulting in formation of mineral veins and ore deposits.
raw_text: Epithermal activity: shallow-depth activity that is low in temperature and pressure, resulting in formation of mineral veins and ore deposits.

sentences.text: Epithermal activity: shallow-depth activity that is low in temperature and pressure, resulting in formation of mineral veins and ore deposits.

clean_text: Exposure: a site or place where rock or softer sediments are visible at the surface. Also known as Outcrop.
raw_text: Exposure: a site or place where rock or softer sediments are visible at the surface. Also known as Outcrop.

sentences.text: Exposure: a site or place where rock or softer sediments are visible at the surface.

clean_text: Exposure sites: geological features that are spatially extensive below ground level actively renewed by erosion or, so that if one site or exposure is lost, another could potentially be excavated nearby. They include exposures in active and disused quarries, coastal and river cliffs, road and rail cuttings, and natural rock outcrops.
raw_text: Exposure sites: geological features that are spatially extensive below ground level actively renewed by erosion or, so that if one site or exposure is lost, another could potentially be excavated nearby. They include exposures in active and disused quarries, coastal and river cliffs, road and rail cuttings, and natural rock outcrops.

sentences.text: Exposure sites: geological features that are spatially extensive below ground level actively renewed by erosion or, so that if one site or exposure is lost, another could potentially be excavated nearby.
They include exposures in active and disused quarries, coastal and river cliffs, road and rail cuttings, and natural rock outcrops.

clean_text: Extinction: in a geological context, an event in the distant past when substantial numbers of existing species disappeared due to natural causes.
raw_text: Extinction: in a geological context, an event in the distant past when substantial numbers of existing species disappeared due to natural causes.

sentences.text: Extinction: in a geological context, an event in the distant past when substantial numbers of existing species disappeared due to natural causes.

clean_text: Extremophiles: species that can withstand extreme conditions, such as darkness in caves or very high temperatures associated with volcanic activity.
raw_text: Extremophiles: species that can withstand extreme conditions, such as darkness in caves or very high temperatures associated with volcanic activity.

sentences.text: Extremophiles: species that can withstand extreme conditions, such as darkness in caves or very high temperatures associated with volcanic activity.

clean_text: Finite sites: features of limited extent that will be depleted and damaged if any of the resource is removed or lost. Examples include geological sites with fossil-bearing rocks of limited extent or a mineral vein deposit.
raw_text: Finite sites: features of limited extent that will be depleted and damaged if any of the resource is removed or lost. Examples include geological sites with fossil-bearing rocks of limited extent or a mineral vein deposit.

sentences.text: Finite sites: features of limited extent that will be depleted and damaged if any of the resource is removed or lost.
Examples include geological sites with fossil-bearing rocks of limited extent or a mineral vein deposit.

clean_text: Fossil: an organic trace or remain of former living matter buried by natural processes and subsequently permanently preserved in rocks.
raw_text: Fossil: an organic trace or remain of former living matter buried by natural processes and subsequently permanently preserved in rocks.

sentences.text: Fossil: an organic trace or remain of former living matter buried by natural processes and subsequently permanently preserved in rocks.

clean_text: Geodiversity: the variety of rocks, minerals, fossils, landforms, sediments and soils, together with the natural processes that form and alter them. It includes past and present geological and geomorphological features and processes that record the history of the Earth and the evolution of life forms as represented in the geological record, including fossils of plants and animals and their habitats.
raw_text: Geodiversity: the variety of rocks, minerals, fossils, landforms, sediments and soils, together with the natural processes that form and alter them. It includes past and present geological and geomorphological features and processes that record the history of the Earth and the evolution of life forms as represented in the geological record, including fossils of plants and animals and their habitats.

sentences.text: Geodiversity: the variety of rocks, minerals, fossils, landforms, sediments and soils, together with the natural processes that form and alter them.

It includes past and present geological and geomorphological features and processes that record the history of the Earth and the evolution of life forms as represented in the geological record, including fossils of plants and animals and their habitats.

clean_text: Geodiversity Action Plan: a plan that defines clear long-term aims and objectives, and sets out measurable shortterm targets and actions, to conserve and enhance the geodiversity and geoheritage of a particular area. It also identifies staffing and financial resources necessary to achieve them. These plans can also assist the integration of geodiversity and geoheritage into the conservation management of different categories of protected area.
raw_text: Geodiversity Action Plan: a plan that defines clear long-term aims and objectives, and sets out measurable shortterm targets and actions, to conserve and enhance the geodiversity and geoheritage of a particular area. It also identifies staffing and financial resources necessary to achieve them. These plans can also assist the integration of geodiversity and geoheritage into the conservation management of different categories of protected area.

sentences.text: Geodiversity Action Plan: a plan that defines clear long-term aims and objectives, and sets out measurable shortterm targets and actions, to conserve and enhance the geodiversity and geoheritage of a particular area.
It also identifies staffing and financial resources necessary to achieve them.
These plans can also assist the integration of geodiversity and geoheritage into the conservation management of different categories of protected area.

clean_text: Geoheritage: those elements, features and processes of geodiversity, either singly or in combination, that are considered to have significant value for intrinsic, scientific, educational, cultural, spiritual, aesthetic, ecological or ecosystem reasons and therefore deserve conservation. Geoheritage constitutes a legacy from the past to be maintained in the present and passed on for the benefit of future generations. Geoheritage records the cumulative story of the Earth preserved in its rocks and landforms, as in the pages of a book. It is represented in special places and objects that are fundamental to our appreciation of the history of the Earth and the evolution of life.
raw_text: Geoheritage: those elements, features and processes of geodiversity, either singly or in combination, that are considered to have significant value for intrinsic, scientific, educational, cultural, spiritual, aesthetic, ecological or ecosystem reasons and therefore deserve conservation. Geoheritage constitutes a legacy from the past to be maintained in the present and passed on for the benefit of future generations. Geoheritage records the cumulative story of the Earth preserved in its rocks and landforms, as in the pages of a book. It is represented in special places (see geosite) and objects (geological specimens in situ and ex situ in museum collections) that are fundamental to our appreciation of the history of the Earth and the evolution of life.

sentences.text: Geoheritage: those elements, features and processes of geodiversity, either singly or in combination, that are considered to have significant value for intrinsic, scientific, educational, cultural, spiritual, aesthetic, ecological or ecosystem reasons and therefore deserve conservation.
Geoheritage constitutes a legacy from the past to be maintained in the present and passed on for the benefit of future generations.
Geoheritage records the cumulative story of the Earth preserved in its rocks and landforms, as in the pages of a book.
It is represented in special places and objects that are fundamental to our appreciation of the history of the Earth and the evolution of life.

clean_text: Geology: the study of the Earth as a whole, its origin, structure, composition and history, and the nature of the processes that gave rise to its past and present states.
raw_text: Geology: the study of the Earth as a whole, its origin, structure, composition and history, and the nature of the processes that gave rise to its past and present states.

sentences.text: Geology: the study of the Earth as a whole, its origin, structure, composition and history, and the nature of the processes that gave rise to its past and present states.

clean_text: Geological timescale: a system of chronological dating of geological strata. It is used by Earth scientists to describe the timing and relationships of events in the history of the Earth, measured in millions and multiples of millions of years.  International Commission of Stratigraphy, March 2020 version reproduced with permission.
raw_text: Geological timescale: a system of chronological dating of geological strata (stratigraphy). It is used by Earth scientists to describe the timing and relationships of events in the history of the Earth, measured in millions and multiples of millions of years.  International Commission of Stratigraphy, March 2020 version reproduced with permission.

sentences.text: Geological timescale: a system of chronological dating of geological strata.
It is used by Earth scientists to describe the timing and relationships of events in the history of the Earth, measured in millions and multiples of millions of years.
International Commission of Stratigraphy, March 2020 version reproduced with permission.

clean_text: Geomorphology: the study of the landforms and processes on and immediately below the surface of the Earth.
raw_text: Geomorphology: the study of the landforms and processes on and immediately below the surface of the Earth.

sentences.text: Geomorphology: the study of the landforms and processes on and immediately below the surface of the Earth.

clean_text: Geopark: a generic term ascribed by a nation or region to an area with outstanding geological heritage aimed at both conservation and promoting its use in a sustainable way. Most Geoparks are not protected areas but they may contain protected areas. See also UNESCO Global Geopark.
raw_text: Geopark: a generic term ascribed by a nation or region to an area with outstanding geological heritage aimed at both conservation and promoting its use in a sustainable way. Most Geoparks are not protected areas but they may contain protected areas. See also UNESCO Global Geopark.

sentences.text: Geopark: a generic term ascribed by a nation or region to an area with outstanding geological heritage aimed at both conservation and promoting its use in a sustainable way.
Most Geoparks are not protected areas but they may contain protected areas.
See also UNESCO Global Geopark.

clean_text: Geoscience: the study of the Earths evolution and the current status of its abiotic aspects. The term comprises geology, geomorphology, geophysics, hydrology and physical geography.
raw_text: Geoscience: the study of the Earths evolution and the current status of its abiotic aspects. The term comprises geology, geomorphology, geophysics, hydrology and physical geography.

sentences.text: Geoscience: the study of the Earths evolution and the current status of its abiotic aspects.
The term comprises geology, geomorphology, geophysics, hydrology and physical geography.

clean_text: Geosite: any site that has a single or a variety of geological or geomorphological features or processes worthy of protection on account of its scientific value. This is short-hand for terms such as geological sites or geomorphological sites.
raw_text: Geosite: any site that has a single or a variety of geological or geomorphological features or processes worthy of protection on account of its scientific value. This is short-hand for terms such as geological sites or geomorphological sites.

sentences.text: Geosite: any site that has a single or a variety of geological or geomorphological features or processes worthy of protection on account of its scientific value.
This is short-hand for terms such as geological sites or geomorphological sites.

clean_text: Geomonitoring: monitoring of particular features and processes to ascertain the state of health of the component interests at a geosite or for a whole system.
raw_text: Geomonitoring (or Site condition monitoring): monitoring of particular features and processes to ascertain the state of health of the component interests at a geosite or for a whole system.

sentences.text: Geomonitoring: monitoring of particular features and processes to ascertain the state of health of the component interests at a geosite or for a whole system.

clean_text: Glacier: snow compressed to form a solid of ice that moves with gravity. It takes various forms. Ice caps and ice sheets are extensive sheets of ice covering large areas such as Antarctica and Greenland, and can occur on a smaller scale as in Iceland and Svalbard. Valley glaciers fill pre-existing valleys and often enlarge them by steepening the sides, as in the Andes and the European Alps for example.

clean_text: Plate tectonics: unifying theory combining continental drift, sea-floor spreading, seismic and volcanic activity, and crustal structures. The Earths blocks of rocks on land and under the sea are formed into eight major and several minor internally rigid plates that are in motion relative to each other. The term also refers to the study of their relative movements over time in the formation of continents and oceans. The margins of the individual plates take various forms; the most important for terrestrial geoconservation are where the plates are colliding or where they are moving apart. Examples of the former are the margins between the Pacific and North American plates, the Pacific and the South American plates, the African and Eurasian plates, and the Indian and Eurasian plates, all of which have played a fundamental role in the evolution of major mountain systems and volcanic activity. In other places, the plates are separating; examples are best manifested on land in Iceland and under the sea along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.

In other places, the plates are separating; examples are best manifested on land in Iceland and under the sea along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.

clean_text: Sedimentary rocks are formed from pre-existing material by soft materials being deposited by water, ice or wind into rivers, lakes and oceans or onto the ground surface, and subsequently transformed to form more solid material. Carbonate rocks, such as limestone, dolostone, and the evaporite rocks, such as gypsum, anhydrite and salt, are particular types of sedimentary rocks found in karst areas. Limestones, sandstones and mudstones are common examples of sedimentary rocks.

clean_text: Speleothems: a general term for all mineral deposits formed in caves. Most are formed of calcite and the precipitation process is the reverse of the limestone dissolution process. Common forms include dripstones and flowstones.
raw_text: Speleothems: a general term for all mineral deposits formed in caves. Most are formed of calcite and the precipitation process is the reverse of the limestone dissolution process. Common forms include dripstones (e.g. stalactites and stalagmites) and flowstones.

Common forms include dripstones and flowstones.

clean_text: Stratigraphy: a branch of geology concerned with the form, arrangement, geographic distribution, chronologic succession and correlation of rock strata with sedimentary origin.

clean_text: Terrane: an area of land where the rocks and structures are of a similar age and type and with a similar early geological history.

clean_text: Tor: a free-standing rock tower formed in situ by weathering of the surrounding weaker rock and its removal downslope.

clean_text: UNESCO Global Geopark: a territory recognised by UNESCO where sites and landscapes of international geological significance are managed within a holistic concept of protection, education and sustainable development. Geoparks are not considered protected areas, but rather as tools for engaging communities and business interests.

clean_text: Unconformity: a discontinuity in the rocks indicating that a time lapse between the lower and upper layers has occurred.
raw_text: Unconformity: a discontinuity in the rocks indicating that a time lapse (which could involve many millions of years) between the lower and upper layers has occurred.

clean_text: Value: the geoheritage value of a site or specimen has a number of components. Intrinsic value means important in itself independently of human appreciation. Scientific value relates to the value for research and education. Aesthetic, cultural and spiritual values refer to human connections, interactions and appreciation of geoheritage. Ecological value relates to supporting biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. The diversity of substrates, landform mosaics and soil formation, together with processes such as water flow regimes, sediment supply, erosion and deposition, provide the foundations for habitats and species and ecosystem functioning. Environmental goods and ecosystem services values relate to the direct and indirect benefits that people receive from the natural environment and properly functioning ecosystems.

clean_text: Volcano: a constructional feature formed by material reaching the Earths surface or on the sea bed through a naturally occurring vent or fracture at the Earths surface supplied from deep inside the Earth. Materials erupting through the fractures or vents are either molten lava, solid pyroclasts, and gaseous water vapour, acidic gases. Eruption styles range from slow and effusive to sudden and explosive. Large volcanoes are often called central volcanoes because of their size in a system or super volcanoes because of the eruptive power with pyroclastic material spread widely around the world through atmospheric circulation. Volcanoes are often, but not always, associated with the movements at the margin of tectonic plates. The chemical composition of the erupted material is highly variable and ranges from acidic to alkaline.
raw_text: Volcano: a constructional feature formed by material reaching the Earths surface or on the sea bed through a naturally occurring vent or fracture at the Earths surface supplied from deep inside the Earth. Materials erupting through the fractures or vents are either molten lava (sometimes with entrained crystals), solid pyroclasts, and gaseous water vapour, acidic gases. Eruption styles range from slow and effusive to sudden and explosive. Large volcanoes are often called central volcanoes because of their size in a system or super volcanoes because of the eruptive power with pyroclastic material spread widely around the world through atmospheric circulation. Volcanoes are often, but not always, associated with the movements at the margin of tectonic plates. The chemical composition of the erupted material is highly variable and ranges from acidic to alkaline.

Eruption styles range from slow and effusive to sudden and explosive.

Large volcanoes are often called central volcanoes because of their size in a system or super volcanoes because of the eruptive power with pyroclastic material spread widely around the world through atmospheric circulation.
Volcanoes are often, but not always, associated with the movements at the margin of tectonic plates.
The chemical composition of the erupted material is highly variable and ranges from acidic to alkaline.

clean_text: Roger Crofts trained as a geographer and specialised in coastal evolution and nature management of protected areas. He was founder Chief Executive of Scottish Natural Heritage, the statutory agency for nature and landscape protection responsible for the implementation of the EU Natura system and the management of the domestic protected area system in Scotland. He has chaired the IUCN UK Committee, the European region of WCPA, the Durban Accord and Action Plan Working Group at the Vth World Parks Conference, and played a leading role in inserting nature in the IUCN protected area definition. He has studied many protected areas and written on geoconservation. Roger was given the Fred Packard International Parks Merit Award in 2016 and has received many other Scottish, UK and Icelandic awards for his environmental management and protected areas work.

clean_text: John Gordon worked for many years with the statutory nature conservation agencies in Great Britain, advising on the assessment, documentation and conservation management of protected areas for geoheritage. He is an Honorary Professor in the School of Geography and Sustainable Development at the University of St Andrews, Scotland. He is a Steering Committee member and a Deputy Chair of the Geoheritage Specialist Group of the IUCN World Commission on Protected Areas, a member of the European Federation of Geologists Panel of Experts on Geoheritage and a member of ProGEO, the European Association for the Conservation of Geological Heritage.

clean_text: John Gunn is an Honorary Professor in the School of Geography, Earth and Environmental Sciences, University of Birmingham. He is a multi-disciplinary scientist working on a single rock  limestone  and on the karst environments that form on limestone. John is a speleologist, actively involved in cave exploration, with research interests in the conservation and management of cave and karst geoheritage and resources; karst hydrogeology; the evolution of karst landform assemblages; and cave climates. He is a Deputy Chair of the Geoheritage Specialist Group of the IUCN WCPA and Chair of the Caves and Karst Working Group.

clean_text: Jonathan Larwood studied geology at University College London and completed a PhD in micropalaeontology at Aberystwyth, University College of Wales. Jonathan has followed a career in geological conservation. He works at the government body Natural England as a geologist and palaeontologist, providing advice on geological and palaeontological conservation. He has been involved in a number of initiatives, including the development of collecting policy and practice and the establishment of geodiversity action planning in the UK, and works closely with the geological voluntary sector. Jonathan is currently the Geologists Associations Archivist, a volunteer advisor to the National Trust, and a Trustee of the Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site.

clean_text: Vincent L. Santucci is Senior Geologist and Palaeontologist in the Geologic Resources Division of the US National Park Service. His career is dedicated to the management, protection, interpretation, scientific research and curation of US National Park System fossils, identified in more than 260 national parks. One of his important functions is to coordinate palaeontological resource planning and activities both within the US National Park Service and with a range of academic, museum and educational partners in order to achieve their resource stewardship and public education missions. One of the most rewarding aspects of his position involves working with the National Fossil Day team to promote an increased awareness about the scientific and educational values of fossils.

clean_text: Dan Tormey is President of Catalyst Environmental Solutions, an environmental consultancy. He has a PhD in Geology and Geochemistry from MIT and a BS in Civil Engineering and Geology from Stanford. He has worked for IUCN on World Heritage since 2009, with 27 desktop reviews for the World Heritage List, one field mission, and co-authorship of the 2019 IUCN Volcano Thematic Study. He has been named to science advisory boards on protected areas by the National Academy of Sciences and the California Council on Science and Technology and is an SPE Distinguished Lecturer and Environmental and Social Responsibility award recipient.

clean_text: Graeme L. Worboys was an Honorary Associate Professor with the Fenner School, Australian National University, and technical advisor to the South Australian Government for the Flinders Ranges World Heritage criterion nomination process. He trained in geology, worked in protected areas for 46 years and gained a PhD for a thesis on protected area management. He completed IUCN geological World Heritage evaluations in South Africa, Italy, India, Vietnam and China. Graeme was lead editor of IUCNs 2015 Protected Area Governance and Management compendium textbook and was awarded in 2016 IUCNs Fred M. Packard International Parks Merit Award for outstanding service in furthering the objectives of protected areas for society. His was awarded the Order of Australia in 2020 for his outstanding service to conservation and the community. He died in September 2020.
raw_text: Graeme L. Worboys was an Honorary Associate Professor with the Fenner School, Australian National University, and technical advisor to the South Australian Government for the Flinders Ranges World Heritage criterion (viii) nomination process. He trained in geology, worked in protected areas for 46 years and gained a PhD for a thesis on protected area management. He completed IUCN geological World Heritage evaluations in South Africa, Italy, India, Vietnam and China. Graeme was lead editor of IUCNs 2015 Protected Area Governance and Management compendium textbook and was awarded in 2016 IUCNs Fred M. Packard International Parks Merit Award for outstanding service in furthering the objectives of protected areas for society. His was awarded the Order of Australia (AM) in 2020 for his outstanding service to conservation and the community. He died in September 2020.
